title: Paul Ukena
text:
Paul Ukena (August 19, 1921 in <a href="Lakota%2C%20Iowa">Lakota, Iowa</a> – March 10, 1991 in <a href="Flemington%2C%20New%20Jersey">Flemington, New Jersey</a>) was an American <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="baritone">baritone</a> and <a href="musical%20theatre">musical theatre</a> <a href="actor">actor</a> who had an active career from the 1940s through the 1970s. After beginning his career entertaining American troops as a part of the <a href="Special%20Services%20%28entertainment%29">Special Services</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, his first critical success was as the baritone soloist in the American premiere of <a href="Frederick%20Delius">Frederick Delius</a>'s "<a href="Requiem%20%28Delius%29">Requiem</a>" in 1950. He was one of the founding members of the <a href="NBC%20Opera%20Theatre">NBC Opera Theatre</a>, a company he performed with throughout the 1950s in such productions as <a href="Benjamin%20Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>'s "<a href="Billy%20Budd%20%28opera%29">Billy Budd</a>" and the world premiere of <a href="Norman%20Dello%20Joio">Norman Dello Joio</a>'s "<a href="The%20Trial%20at%20Rouen">The Trial at Rouen</a>".
Ukena also enjoyed a lengthy association with the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> (NYCO) from 1958 to 1979. At the NYCO he notably appeared in a number of world premieres including <a href="Hugo%20Weisgall">Hugo Weisgall</a>'s "<a href="Six%20Characters%20in%20Search%20of%20an%20Author%20%28opera%29">Six Characters in Search of an Author</a>" (1959), <a href="Robert%20Ward%20%28composer%29">Robert Ward</a>'s "<a href="The%20Crucible%20%28opera%29">The Crucible</a>" (1961), and <a href="Dominick%20Argento">Dominick Argento</a>'s "<a href="Miss%20Havisham%27s%20Fire">Miss Havisham's Fire</a>" (1979). At the NYCO he also starred in the United States premiere of <a href="Josef%20Tal">Josef Tal</a>'s "<a href="Ashmedai%20%28opera%29">Ashmedai</a>" in 1976. He also served as musical director and conductor for the 1953 Broadway musical "Maggie". He starred in the Off-Broadway musicals "<a href="Sandhog%20%28musical%29">Sandhog</a>" (1954), and "<a href="Hotel%20for%20Criminals">Hotel for Criminals</a>" (1974), and appeared in the Broadway musical "<a href="Cry%20for%20Us%20All">Cry for Us All</a>" (1970).
After the 1970s, Ukena's performance appearances became rarer as he devoted his time to teaching at <a href="Sarah%20Lawrence%20College">Sarah Lawrence College</a> in <a href="Yonkers%2C%20New%20York">Yonkers, New York</a> where he was a professor from 1961 until his retirement in 1989. He also was a faculty member at the <a href="Mannes%20College%20of%20Music">Mannes College of Music</a> in the 1970s.
Early life, education and career with the NBC Opera Theatre.
Born in Lakota, Iowa, to Juren Eiken “Jerry Ukena and Doris Wortmann Ukena, Ukena earned a Bachelor of Music in vocal performance from the <a href="University%20of%20Dubuque">University of Dubuque</a> in 1943. After graduation he served as a Private in the <a href="Special%20Services%20%28entertainment%29">Special Services</a> department of the <a href="Army%20Service%20Forces">Army Service Forces</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in which he entertained American troops in performances of stage works like <a href="Sigmund%20Romberg">Sigmund Romberg</a>'s "<a href="The%20New%20Moon">The New Moon</a>" After the war he pursued graduate studies in opera at <a href="Southern%20Methodist%20University">Southern Methodist University</a> in 1945 and then at the <a href="Juilliard%20School">Juilliard School</a> where he earned a Master of Music in 1950. While a student at Juilliard he made his professional concert debut in 1947 at <a href="Carnegie%20Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> as the baritone soloist in the world premiere of <a href="Charles%20F.%20Bryan">Charles F. Bryan</a>'s "Bell Witch Cantata" with <a href="Robert%20Shaw%20%28conductor%29">Robert Shaw</a> conducting. He appeared as a soloist in several concerts with the <a href="Robert%20Shaw%20Chorale">Robert Shaw Chorale</a> during his early career, and is a featured soloist on the choir's 1954 album "With Love From A Chorus" on the <a href="RCA-Victor">RCA-Victor</a> label.
Ukena's first critical success came on the concert stage when he served as the baritone soloist in the United States premiere of <a href="Frederick%20Delius">Frederick Delius</a>'s "<a href="Requiem%20%28Delius%29">Requiem</a>" on November 6, 1950 at <a href="Carnegie%20Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> with the <a href="Collegiate%20Chorale">Collegiate Chorale</a>, the National Orchestra Association under the baton of William Johnson. He made his professional opera debut a month later with the <a href="NBC%20Opera%20Theatre">NBC Opera Theatre</a> (NBCOT) on <a href="Christmas%20Day">Christmas Day</a> 1950 as Peter, the broom-maker, in <a href="Engelbert%20Humperdinck%20%28composer%29">Engelbert Humperdinck</a>'s "<a href="Hansel%20and%20Gretel%20%28opera%29">Hansel and Gretel</a>". He continued to perform regularly with the NBCOT through 1957, notably creating roles in the world premieres of <a href="Lukas%20Foss">Lukas Foss</a>'s "<a href="Griffelkin">Griffelkin</a>" (1955, as Uncle Skelter) and <a href="Norman%20Dello%20Joio">Norman Dello Joio</a>'s "<a href="The%20Triumph%20of%20St.%20Joan">The Trial at Rouen</a>" (1956, as the Jailer).

Work with the New York City Opera and other opera and concert work.
In 1954 Ukena created the role of Tranio in the world premiere of <a href="Vittorio%20Giannini">Vittorio Giannini</a>'s "<a href="The%20Taming%20of%20the%20Shrew%20%28Giannini%29">The Taming of the Shrew</a>" for the NBCOT. He reprised the role for his debut with the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> (NYCO) in April 1958. He continued to perform regularly with the NYCO through 1979, notably creating roles in the world premieres of <a href="Hugo%20Weisgall">Hugo Weisgall</a>'s "<a href="Six%20Characters%20in%20Search%20of%20an%20Author%20%28opera%29">Six Characters in Search of an Author</a>" (1959, The Father), <a href="Robert%20Ward%20%28composer%29">Robert Ward</a>'s "<a href="The%20Crucible%20%28opera%29">The Crucible</a>" (1961, <a href="Thomas%20Putnam">Thomas Putnam</a>), <a href="Douglas%20Moore">Douglas Moore</a>'s "<a href="The%20Wings%20of%20the%20Dove%20%28opera%29">The Wings of the Dove</a>" (1961, Homer Croy), and <a href="Dominick%20Argento">Dominick Argento</a>'s "<a href="Miss%20Havisham%27s%20Fire">Miss Havisham's Fire</a>" (1979, Old Orlick).
Other roles he performed with the NYCO included:
Ukena also appeared in operas with other companies during the 1950s and 1960s. In 1954 he sang the role of Giorgio in Rossini's "<a href="La%20gazza%20ladra">La gazza ladra</a>" with <a href="Arnold%20Gamson">Arnold Gamson</a>'s <a href="American%20Opera%20Society">American Opera Society</a>. In 1960 he portrayed Leporello in Mozart's "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>" with the <a href="Goldovsky%20Opera%20Theater">Goldovsky Opera Theater</a>. To make the offer of the tour sweeter, Goldovsky offered him the rôles of Don Giovanni and Leporello on different nights; Ukena said that he could only afford to do the tour if he were also allowed to sing the rôle of Masetto. Goldowsky agreed to this. Ron Holgate, who also sang the rôle of Don Giovanni during this tour (Sherrill Milnes also sang Masetto – his opera debut – on this tour), has said that therefore Ukena sang one of the three rôles in every performance of the entire tour. In 1956 he created the title role in the world premiere of <a href="Robert%20Ward%20%28composer%29">Robert Ward</a>'s "<a href="He%20Who%20Gets%20Slapped%20%28opera%29">Pantaloon</a>" (later renamed "He Who Gets Slapped") with the Columbia Theatre Associates and Opera Workshop. In 1963 he portrayed Don Pizzaro in Beethoven's "<a href="Fidelio">Fidelio</a>" with the <a href="Israel%20National%20Opera">Israel National Opera</a> in Tel Aviv with conductor <a href="William%20Steinberg">William Steinberg</a>. In 1965 he portrayed The Peasant in <a href="Carl%20Orff">Carl Orff</a>'s "<a href="Die%20Kluge">Die Kluge</a>" at the <a href="Caramoor%20Summer%20Music%20Festival">Caramoor Summer Music Festival</a>. On the concert stage he sang in concerts with the <a href="Cleveland%20Orchestra">Cleveland Orchestra</a>, the <a href="New%20York%20Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a>, and the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra</a>.
Work in musical theater.
Ukena periodically appeared in musicals as well as opera, beginning with the original production of <a href="Gordon%20Jenkins">Gordon Jenkins</a>'s "Heaven Come Wednesday" with <a href="Jean%20Stapleton">Jean Stapleton</a> and <a href="Paul%20Mann">Paul Mann</a> at the Keene Summer Theatre, in <a href="Keene%2C%20New%20Hampshire">Keene, New Hampshire</a> which opened on August 27, 1951. In 1952 he portrayed Fred Graham (and Petruchio) in <a href="Cole%20Porter">Cole Porter</a>'s "<a href="Kiss%20Me%2C%20Kate">Kiss Me, Kate</a>" at the South Shore Music Circus in Massachusetts and the Lakes Region Playhouse in New Hampshire with <a href="Elaine%20Malbin">Elaine Malbin</a> as Lilli and <a href="Betty%20George">Betty George</a> as Lisa Kirk. He served as music director and conductor for the original production of William Roy's "Maggie" which opened in January 1953 at the <a href="Forrest%20Theatre">Forrest Theatre</a> in Philadelphia before transferring to the <a href="Nederlander%20Theatre">National Theatre</a> on <a href="Broadway%20%28theatre%29">Broadway</a> the following March. He appeared in several musicals with the Fort Wayne Light Opera at the Foellinger Outdoor Theatre in Franke Park, including "Kiss Me Kate" (1953, Fred Graham) and <a href="Rodgers%20and%20Hammerstein">Rodgers and Hammerstein</a>'s "<a href="Carousel%20%28musical%29">Carousel</a>" (1954, Billy).
In 1954 Ukena made his <a href="Off-Broadway">Off-Broadway</a> debut at the <a href="Phoenix%20Theatre%20%28New%20York%20City%29">Phoenix Theatre</a> as Fred Burger in <a href="Earl%20Robinson">Earl Robinson</a> and <a href="Waldo%20Salt">Waldo Salt</a>'s "<a href="Sandhog%20%28musical%29">Sandhog</a>" which was directed by <a href="Howard%20Da%20Silva">Howard Da Silva</a> and used choreography by <a href="Sophie%20Maslow">Sophie Maslow</a>. In 1955 he portrayed the role of Carl Linden in <a href="No%C3%ABl%20Coward">Noël Coward</a>'s "<a href="Bitter%20Sweet%20%28operetta%29">Bitter Sweet</a>" at the <a href="Music%20Hall%20at%20Fair%20Park">Music Hall at Fair Park</a> in Dallas. He returned there the following year to star alongside <a href="Liberace">Liberace</a> and his brother <a href="George%20Liberace">George</a> in <a href="Hassard%20Short">Hassard Short</a>'s "<a href="The%20Great%20Waltz">The Great Waltz</a>". In 1956 he starred as Kubla Khan in the television musical "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Marco%20Polo">The Adventures of Marco Polo</a>" which was directed and produced by <a href="Max%20Liebman">Max Liebman</a> for NBC with <a href="Neil%20Simon">Neil Simon</a> as writer with music by <a href="Buck%20Warnick">Clay Warnick</a>. In 1958 he portrayed <a href="Frank%20E.%20Butler">Frank E. Butler</a> in <a href="Irving%20Berlin">Irving Berlin</a>'s "<a href="Annie%20Get%20Your%20Gun%20%28musical%29">Annie Get Your Gun</a>" at Herb Rogers's Tenthouse Theater in the Round in Chicago with <a href="Helen%20Gallagher">Helen Gallagher</a> in the title role. In 1959 he starred with <a href="Ruth%20McDevitt">Ruth McDevitt</a> in "The Golden Wheel", a musical mounted by <a href="General%20Motors">General Motors</a> to promote the <a href="cadillac">cadillac</a>, at the <a href="Waldorf%20Astoria%20New%20York">Waldorf Astoria New York</a>. In 1969 he toured New England as Emile De Becque in Rodgers and Hammerstein's "<a href="South%20Pacific%20%28musical%29">South Pacific</a>"; appearing at theaters like the Ogunquit Playhouse in Ogunquit, Maine and the Cape Playhouse in Dennis, Massachusetts.
In 1970 Ukena starred as Paul Haggerty in <a href="Mitch%20Leigh">Mitch Leigh</a>'s short lived Broadway musical "<a href="Cry%20For%20Us%20All">Cry For Us All</a>", and is featured on the original cast album of that show. In 1974 he starred as Fantomas in <a href="Richard%20Foreman">Richard Foreman</a> and <a href="Stanley%20Silverman">Stanley Silverman</a>'s horror musical "<a href="Hotel%20for%20Criminals">Hotel for Criminals</a>" which premiered in Lennox, Massachusetts at the Lenox Arts Center in August 1974 before transferring to the <a href="Off-Broadway">Off-Broadway</a> Westbeth Theatre Center in New York City the following December.
Personal life and teaching career.
After the 1970s, Ukena's performances became rarer as he devoted his time to teaching. After graduation from Juilliard, he joined the faculty, where he remained until 1961, when he joined the music faculty at <a href="Sarah%20Lawrence%20College">Sarah Lawrence College</a> in <a href="Yonkers%2C%20New%20York">Yonkers, New York</a>, where he taught until his retirement in 1989. While on the faculty at Juilliard, he was in the Juilliard Opera Theater's production of the first English translation of Rossini's "Count Ory" which hadn't been seen in the U.S. since 1831. The production's sets and special effects were by Saul Steinberg. He was a guest artist with the Laurentian String Quartet in 1984 in a concert at SLC performing music by Mozart, Bartok, and Schoek. He also taught on the faculty of the <a href="Mannes%20College%20of%20Music">Mannes College of Music</a> in the 1970s. At Mannes he directed several opera productions, including stagings of <a href="Gian%20Carlo%20Menotti">Gian Carlo Menotti</a>'s "<a href="The%20Old%20Maid%20and%20the%20Thief">The Old Maid and the Thief</a>", <a href="Carl%20Maria%20von%20Weber">Carl Maria von Weber</a>'s "<a href="Abu%20Hassan">Abu Hassan</a>", and the United States premiere of <a href="Wolfgang%20Fortner">Wolfgang Fortner</a>'s "Corinna" (with an English translation by Ukena) at the <a href="92nd%20Street%20Y">92nd Street Y</a> in 1972.
Ukena's wife, Meta Ukena, was a music teacher for <a href="Pelham%20Public%20Schools">Pelham Public Schools</a> in Pelham, New York where the couple resided for thirty-five years. They had five children. Ukena died of heart failure on March 10, 1991 at <a href="Hunterdon%20Medical%20Center">Hunterdon Medical Center</a> in New Jersey while visiting a daughter in Lebanon, New Jersey. Just prior to his death, he and his wife had moved to Mount Vernon, New York.
